label: Letter to Angelina Grimke and Anna R. Frost from Elizabeth Caroline Grimke, 1834
description: Letter from Elizabeth Caroline Grimke to her sisters Angelina Grimke and Mrs. Anna Rutledge Grimke Frost regarding the death of their brother Thomas Smith Grimke, and the impact it had on his widow and a family member named John.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Elizabeth Caroline Grimke to her sisters Angelina Grimke and Mrs. Anna Rutledge Grimke Frost regarding the death of their brother Thomas Smith Grimke, and the impact it had on his widow and a family member named John.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information and reuse requirements contact Special Collections at Addlestone Library, College of Charleston, Charleston, SC, 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 dpi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Thursday

I have [non?] [illegible] of your letters before me the answer Dear
Sister, and as I [reason?] you will feel much anxiety to kind
[hon?] from John as, I will not delay writing, he arrived
Tuesday night about 8. I went down to see him yes-
terday, indeed I have been there every day since Sis-
ters affliction- John was [confessed?], though much af-
fected it seeming me, I had but little conversation
with him, first Sister told me she [said?] the hand of
God most [illegible] in his [illegible] detained in Phil. un-
til he heard of and saw Brothers death, she thought
his [being?] with religious pleasure had had a great
affect on him and he had resolved by the grace of God
to devote himself to a religious life. She said in the
morning he had [assembled?] the days in her chamber the
family prayers; but after going [thus?] the [illegible] in
the prayer [health?] he [endorsed?] it and offered [up?] an [astern?]
[illegible] prayer of his own. Mr Barnwell visited her in
the morning she sent for John and introduced him,
Mr B then had a long conversation with him oh
Dear Sister if the death of one Brother was necessary
for the salvation of this one soul, shall we not
rejoice that he was [illegible]ren none I believe feel his
loss more than poor Lucy [L'Duaiale?], she was with

[crosswriting:] Henry says there will be no occasion for you to come her to act as Guardian
late Angelina I think she had better return John the $ [illegible]
she must have reexamined the check for $[illegible] [that] his Father dis[illegible]
ted it paid. and I also you kindly mentioned the no in Philadel-
phia he had not paid for his clothes- if it is I do believe best
to have anything to do with that family about money and even
Johns mind might be prejudiced against us- if left to
himself I fear nothing.

[End page 1]

Sister constantly until Saturday night, she went
home wild and exhausted, after remaining many hours in
a state of deep despair, at 1/2 past 2. she sent for
Mr. Barnwell, he remained with her until daylight
on Sunday [illegible] her all [composure] she was with Sister
she had [illegible] what Grace God had giver her-
[on?] Monday she opened her [illegible], tho' her friends except Mr
B. advised not, she said Brother would have told her
to do it, and she would therefore act according to what
she believed he [would?] have wished- yesterday she was too
[frail?] to do so, but I believe I can [Long?] will he strength-
ened for her work. Sister [illegible] composed when I saw
her yesterday, she says she is resigned and that if life is
spared, she will devote herself to bringing up her children
religiously, I [illegible] she is not [illegible]izing herself, and that
she may have built her hope on a true [rock?], but there
has even been a depth about Sister I [could?] not [farther?]
we must leave her in the hands of God. [Illegible] as well
and is enjoying much peace and calmness. She desires her love
to you all, and says whenever her head and eyes will dmit
of her writing she will do so. How fortunate now Dearest
Sister that I came when I did, oh! God was good and [illegible]id
to upon [illegible] a plain and comfortable way for [illegible]
home, for I felt I was to come tho' I said not the way as
Angelina can tell you-

[End page 2]

As regards your first letter, I would only say that I fear
you anticipated too much, for myself I believe I was often
discontented without a cause, I have by no means resolved
never to visit you again, tho' even before I went I said
I believed it to [be?] my farewell visit, I have only resolved
that if I come again, I will not burthen myself with the
care of a child but be free to enjoy you all, and now to Dear
Mary Anna, tell me how she walks, [I?] she says she has
lost her cough, I Read she felt deeply, for fear [Father?] is
dead, we all must who Know his father, and in Knowing
him, know what he lost: I feel very sorry that you have
refused the [illegible] my gift of the $10. I would have
bought something for you, but as you always said [you?]
preferred a present of money, I left it for you. I feel
mortified at it, for Dear Sister when I did I [can?] re-
fuse any thing you offered me- I still hope you will
oblige me in this particular and shall write to [illegible] to
pay it. and also [give?] 6. for Bess from Mother. let me know
if that pays for the year, or whether [Dee?] is still unpaid, I
do not remember nor does Mother- my [loan?] to Dear Sister
and all [at?] to all my friends also- [Afft oblige?]
Dear Angelina to send G. B's [help?] [health?] without [leaving?] [illegible]
ad. pay Sister Anna from me $16. I have written about
it. I should be glad to know as soon as Sister buys the

[End page 3]

buys the servants things and Mother when and you B[illegible]
what the 3 [illegible] sent by Selma [are?]; I should hope
to know how our [ale?] stands. for the $ [illegible]. Stephen did not
wish his umbrella to cost more than $3. Sister Mary
has give me my mourning- thus you see tho' Dear Bro-
ther [has?] gone who always considered [illegible] on the [illegible]

[To]: Miss Angelina Grimke
Mrs Anna R. Frost
56th North 4
Philadelphia

God has found another instrument by which to [Listen?] his [glories?]
and allowed me without any any inconvenience to pay a proper
respect to his memory and you had better take care of the
letter from [Barton?] on Mr. G. in which there is an offer made by
some Bond[illegible] to take 200 copies of [Dymond?] with much
love to yourself Dear Sister S. [and] Catherine Afft. E-

[End page 4]
